title: Vladimír Dzurilla
text:
Vladimír Dzurilla (August 2, 1942 in <a href="Bratislava">Bratislava</a>, <a href="Slovak%20Republic%20%281939%E2%80%931945%29">Slovakia</a> – July 27, 1995 in <a href="D%C3%BCsseldorf">Düsseldorf</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a>) was a <a href="Slovaks">Slovak</a> <a href="ice%20hockey">ice hockey</a> goaltender playing for <a href="Czechoslovakia">Czechoslovakia</a>.
Dzurilla, a refrigerator repairman by profession, was goalie for the Czechoslovak national team for over 16 years, winning three gold, three silver and four bronze medals at <a href="Ice%20Hockey%20World%20Championships">world championships</a> as well as one silver and two bronze <a href="Olympic%20medals">Olympic medals</a>. However, in most of these tournaments Dzurilla and <a href="Jiri%20Holecek">Jiri Holecek</a> were battling to be Czechoslovakia's top goaltender and each were given their share of games.
For North American fans, he is mostly known for stopping 29 shots in a 1-0 win over <a href="Canada">Canada</a> in the <a href="1976%20Canada%20Cup">1976 Canada Cup</a> (where the Czechoslovaks finished second).
He suffered a fatal heart attack at his home in Düsseldorf, Germany on July 27, 1995, only days before his 53rd birthday.
